III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/20/24 Youth A alleged Staff 1 poked her in the stomach and
pinched and bent her fingers back.
Investigation Girlstown is a non-secure treatment facility located in a residential
neighborhood in Belleville. The facility does not use or train staff
in physical restraint. They rely on law enforcement to intervene in
crisis situations.
Interviews:
I was assigned this investigation on 6/21/24 and notified
Residential Director of the allegation by phone.
I attempted to reach Complainant on 6/24/24 and 6/25/24, but the
number was out of service.
On 6/24/24 I notified Youth A’s Foster Care Worker of the
investigation assignment via email.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 6/25/24. She said she has
known Staff 1 for six months and never got along well with her.
Prior to the alleged incident, Youth A said she was arguing with
various staff members, but she could not recall what she was
arguing about. “I tried to leave my room and Supervisor stood in
front of my door. Staff 1 poked my side with her pointy nails and
kept laughing. Then Staff 1 pinched my fingers and bent them
back.” Youth A said she did not know why Staff 1 pinched and
bent her fingers. “The cops came and took me.”
Youth A said the incident happened in her bedroom where there
are no cameras. She said no one saw Staff 1 poke her side or
pinch and bend her fingers back. Youth A denied having any
2

marks or bruises as a result of the poking and bending. I
observed Youth A’s hands and saw no evidence of injury.
On 6/26/24 Government Worker was assigned to a similar
investigation so while this was not a joint investigation, portions of
it were completed jointly.
I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government Worker on
7/1/24. She has worked at the facility for five years. On the
evening of 6/20/24, Supervisor said she went upstairs where the
youth’s bedrooms are located and saw Youth A yelling, cussing
and threatening others. Youth A and Staff 2 were in Youth A’s
bedroom as Supervisor stood in the doorway. Staff 1 entered the
youth’s bedroom. “Youth A kept trying to come out of the room.
She kept trying to push to get through me forcefully bumping me.
The other girls wanted to get at her. I was afraid they would hurt
her. Youth A put her hands on Staff 2 arms. Staff 1 and I got her
off. Youth A kicked Staff 1 on her leg. I asked Staff 1 to go call
the police. The police arrived within ten minutes. Youth A swung
at police and refused their directions. I came downstairs to gather
paperwork.”
Supervisor said Youth A was not injured after this incident and
denied seeing Staff 1 poke, pinch or bend the youth’s fingers
back.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker on 7/1/24.
She has worked at the facility for over a year. Staff 1 said Youth A
got mad when she was asked to remove her clothes from the
shared bathroom. “She wouldn’t follow directives and threw a
book at staff. We told her to stop. Youth T ran full force toward
Staff 2 and grabbed and held her arms. I massaged her hand to
release her grip. She instantly kicked my upper thigh…The kids
threatened to hurt her if she hit staff. We protected her from the
other girls.”
I asked Staff 1 to describe how she “massaged” Youth T’s hand to
release her grip on Staff 2. She demonstrated a commonly used
CPI defensive technique designed to immobilize a person’s hand
and minimize injury and said Staff 2 taught her this move. She
denied poking Youth A in her side or stomach.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker on 7/1/24 via
phone. She has worked at the facility for nine years. Staff 2
recalled “Youth A was verbally abusive to me and Staff 1. The
other kids wanted to attack her. She tried to get through me and
3

Supervisor because she wanted to fight the girls who wanted to
fight her. Youth A grabbed my arm. Staff 1 got her loose from my
arm…I did not see if Staff 1 bent her fingers or not…I have used
the CPI ‘release grip’ in the past…I did not see Staff 1 poke or
push her side or stomach.”
Documents reviewed:
An incident report by Staff 2 dated 6/20/24 at 8:45pm indicated
Youth A was noncompliant when asked to remove her clothes off
the bathroom floor. She yelled, swore and called staff “bitches.”
Youth A went into her room continuing abusive language. The
other girls screamed at her. Supervisor was called to assist.
Youth A tried to push past staff, grabbed Staff 2’s arm. Staff 1
assisted in getting Youth A’s hand away. Youth A tried to leave
the room. Staff had to get the other girls to their rooms because
they were trying to get to Youth A. Youth A pushed, kicked and hit
staff then calmed down when she saw the police pull up. Youth A
was handcuffed and taken by police.
I reviewed a Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) manual obtained
from another child caring institution that uses it. I identified the
One-Hand Hair Pull Release as a protective technique resembling
how Staff 1 described “massaging” Youth A’s hand to loosen her
grip. For this technique the manual instructs staff to immobilize
this grab by securing the person’s hand, to your head in the case
of hairpulling. By using one or both of your hands to immobilize
the person’s hand, you can prevent further grabbing of hair and
minimize injury. Move your head toward the person, leveraging
the arm position to a 45-degree angle. The grip of the hair pull is
levered backward, reducing the strength of the grip and opening
up the weak point of the grab at the fingers. At the same time,
you can gain a psychological advantage by using verbal
distraction or an element of surprise. As your hair is released,
attempt to move out of the way to maintain safety. In this case,
Staff 1 used a version of this technique to loosen Youth A’s grip
from another staff’s arm instead of from her own hair.
Analysis There is no evidence Staff 1 poked Youth A in the side or stomach
with her fingernail. Although Staff 1 is not formally trained in
physical management, she said she utilized a version of a
defensive technique she learned informally in order to loosen and
remove Youth A’s grip from Staff 2’s arm. Youth T did not sustain
any injuries as a result of Staff 1 removing the youth’s grip from
Staff 2’s arm.
4

CONSULTATION
Girlstown staff should not use defensive techniques on which they
are not trained. If on occasion staff need to use such techniques,
they should be trained.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
